2009/7/27 Jeff Clune <jclune@...>:
>
>
>> Reading Jean-Baptiste's response got me thinking that there's a
>> broader question here about the elimintation of connections with low
>> weight (e.g.+-0.2). The 'pure' approach is to leave them in, the
[...]

> While I agree that there could be a performance boost for very large and
> sparse networks by eliminating links, I do not think the current code base
> gets any performance boost from 'missing' links, because the links are still
> there and are just set to 0.

If I'm remembering right, if the links are still there then there is
no need to apply the +-0.2 cut-off. The only purpose of the cut-off is
to restrict the number of connections in the resulting ANN that must
be simulated.


>>However
>> there may be better alternatives:
[...]
>> 3) Use HybrID to refine *all* of the weights over their full range,
>> regardles of whether they were eliminated during the HyperNEAT phase.
>
> If I understand you correctly, this is what we did in the paper.

Yes.

>> This then raises the question of how much HybrID's performance is down
>> to this effect.
>
> I do not understand what you mean by this comment. Can you expand it a bit?

Sure. Assuming you did use a cut-off of +-0.2 (or so) then I'm
suggesting that this may be a disadvantage to HyperNeat because it
cannot express connection weights in the +-0.2 range - because they
get zeroed. If it is a significant disadvantage then perhaps some of
the advantage of HybrID is due to it's adjusting some of the
connections weights (zeroed or otherwise) into the +-0.2 range.



>> Even more broadly, given the potentially huge resource cost of ANNs
>> generated by CPPNs perhaps we should consider factoring that cost into
>> the fitness functions. That way we allow evolution to find the sweet
>> spot between good performance on the objective function and lousy
>> resource utilisation (which slows down search speed and thus the power
>> of the overall search method)
>
> That is a cool idea. It would be cool to see someone try it.

It's trivially simple to add a genome size punishment factor into the
fitness function, just use something like:

     fitness = fitness / (connectionCount + C)

and maybe scale the fitness back up with some fixed multiple, so:

  fitness = (fitness * A) / (connectionCount + C)

I've also used this approach to limit overfitting of target data, put
simply, smaller ANNs are less likely to specialize and overfit than
larger ones. I guess you could say it's a form of regularization.

Cheers,

Colin.
